Subject: Editors, Publishers, and Readers-- What Rules to Break and Which Don't Apply
Description: Many new authors have heard the rules: One POV per scene, don't use adverbs, Limit the POVs to no more than three per story. These 'rules' have been taught for over a hundred years, but who came up with them and do they still apply to the modern reader?  Speakers include:Ann Leckie, Michael K. Elliot, Steven Saus, Tobias S. Buckell

Subject: Social Media for Writers
Description: What social media trends are necessary for the writer building their web foot print? What are some important things to do, and what should you not do?  Speakers include:David Erik Nelson, Michael W. Lucas, Christopher Purrett, Alex Kourvo, Mark Oshiro, Mary Lynne Gibbs

Subject: Writing Group 101
Description: How to survive and thrive in a writing group.  Speakers include:Christian Klaver, David Erik Nelson, Cindy Spencer Pape

Subject: Editing for Your Spouse/Partner/BFF/Pet
Description: 'Can you read this and tell me what you think?' is a question to test any relationship. We will learn some ways to navigate that communications mine-field while musing on the nature of editing, the care and feeding of your larval writer and some small, practical steps towards upping our editing game.  Speakers include:Scott Favre, Clif Flynt, Janice Leach, Jim Leach, Michael Cieslak

Subject: History in Speculative Fiction (and Other Literature)
Description: The historical details can bring a story to life or bog it down. What's the right balance?  Speakers include:Clif Flynt, Steven Saus, Nicole Castle, Robert Kroese, Michael Cieslak

Subject: Poetry Starter Kit
Description: Audience Participation Panel: Speculative Poetry Starter Kit: who to read, where to look and exactly what the heck IS speculative poetry.  Speakers include:Jim Leach, Sean M Davis

Subject: KaffeKlatsch with Catherynne Valente
Description: Join Guest of Honor Catherynne Valente for coffee and chatting!  This is a limited attendance event.  Please sign up in advance at Ops.  Speakers include:Catherynne Valente

Subject: First Things First: Story Titles
Description: First Things First: Story Titles: Which comes first, a story or its title? What makes a good title? Who gets to decide what that title would be? Should a title hint at the story to come, or only make sense after the story is read?   Speakers include:Jon David, Alex Kourvo, Christine Daigle

Subject: Reading/Signing: John Scalzi and Dave Klecha
Description: Join our attending authors in the Writers Block (317 & 318) for readings and signings!  Speakers include:John Scalzi, David Klecha

Subject: The Reality and Fiction of Artificial Intelligence
Description: Artificial intelligences have been a staple of science fiction forever.  But where does the reality of AI end, and the fiction begin?    Speakers include:Ann Leckie, Jason Mars, Lingjia Tang, Jennifer Marsman

Subject: Evoking Emotions, Provoking Readers
Description: Creating authentic characters who seem to experience a full range of believable emotions is only half the equation in character-building.  How can we use character emotions to evoke real feelings in our readers? What other tricks are there?  Speakers include:Merrie Haskell, Cindy Spencer Pape, Ken MacGregor, Catherynne Valente, Mark Oshiro

Subject: A Writer's Life
Description: How do you handle the daily mechanics of hammering your magical, sparking, glittering craft into the finished product that could sell. What practical habits foster the creative process on a daily basis and how do you manage the emotional blender that is making words ready for publishing?   Speakers include:Tobias S. Buckell, Ferrett Steinmetz, Catherynne Valente, Dave Klecha, Andrew Zimmerman Jones

Subject: Reading/Signing: Jen Haeger and Mary Lynne Gibbs
Description: Join our attending authors in the Writers Block (317 & 318) for readings and signings!  Speakers include:Jen Haeger, Mary Lynne Gibbs

Subject: Pupal Writers Panel
Description: You've written a bit, you've published a bit, now what?  Speakers include:Jen Haeger, Christian Klaver, Ken MacGregor, Christopher Purrett, Janice Leach

Subject: Where Did the Heroes Go?
Description: Science fiction and fantasy were once known for stories with strong, capable heroes and heroines. We take a look at heroes and what's happened to them lately.  Speakers include:Jay Maynard, Eric S. Raymond, Jon David, Stewart Sternberg

Subject: Reading/Signing: Alex Kourvo/M.H. Mead and Ferrett Steinmetz
Description: Join our attending authors in the Writers Block (317 & 318) for readings and signings!  Speakers include:Alex Kourvo, Ferrett Steinmetz

Subject: Writing the Alien
Description: The challenge of writing an intelligence unlike our own lies at the heart of much of our best science fiction. How does an author tackle this difficult task?  Speakers include:Tobias S. Buckell, Ferrett Steinmetz, Ramses Alcaide

Subject: Character Problems - What's an Author to Do?
Description: A main character needs to start out annoying, boring, or unappealing. (they have to grow from somewhere!) Your readers say 'ugh' and set your book aside. What's an author to do? How do we avoid this? Examples?  Speakers include:Mary Lynne Gibbs, Paul Kemner, Emmy Jackson, Cindy Spencer Pape, Jeff Pryor

Subject: Reading/Signing: Michael Cieslak and Nicole Castle
Description: Join our attending authors in the Writers Block (317 & 318) for readings and signings!  Speakers include:Michael Cieslak, Nicole Castle

Subject: How Will Technology Change Society?
Description: How we develop our technology may determine the world we will have in the future. Will it be a world of increasing personal freedom, or a totalitarian dystopia? And are we making that decision right now without knowing it?  Speakers include:Deb Nicholson, Jason Mars, Lingjia Tang, Tobias S. Buckell, Edward L. Platt

Subject: Finding an Agent
Description: What are the best methods for finding the best agent for you?  Speakers include:Merrie Haskell, Ann Leckie, Mary Lynne Gibbs, Christine Daigle

Subject: Writing Fast and Slow
Description: Are you a hack if you write quickly? Are you an amateur if you write slowly? How many books a year should a working writer produce, and how has that expectation changed in todays publishing climate? How quickly do readers want or expect the next book?  Speakers include:Alex Kourvo, Jen Haeger, Jim Leach, Catherynne Valente, Jeff Pryor

Subject: Reading/Signing: Cindy Spencer Pape
Description: Join our attending authors in the Writers Block (317 & 318) for readings and signings!  Speakers include:Cindy Spencer Pape

Subject: Acts of Shameless Self-Promotion
Description: What's the best way to get your name forward?  Speakers include:Dave Klecha, Michael W. Lucas, Jackie Morgan, Steven Saus

Subject: Reading/Signing: Christopher Purrett and Merrie Haskell
Description: Join our attending authors in the Writers Block (317 & 318) for readings and signings!  Speakers include:Christopher Purrett, Merrie Haskell

Subject: Ann Leckie Reading
Description: Join Guest of Honor Ann Leckie for a reading and a chance to have your books signed.  Speakers include:Ann Leckie

Subject: Dragons, Demons, and the Laundry
Description: With Urban Fantasy being such an enormous field, how do you keep the sense of wonder in magical spells, fantastic creatures and other mystical phenomenon. Is this required and what is the cost if it's missing? Do characters look differently at magic if it's used to handle mundane tasks and what does this mean to the setting?  Speakers include:Christian Klaver, Robert Kroese, Michael Cieslak, Andrea Johnson, Cindy Spencer Pape

Subject: Reading/Signing: Paul Kemner and Jon David
Description: Join our attending authors in the Writers Block (317 & 318) for readings and signings!  Speakers include:Paul Kemner, Jon David

Subject: Writing Workshop
Description: Join us for a hands on workshop where writers would bring their pens, pencils, notepads, laptops, etc. to participate in numerous whimsical writing exercises. Exercises will consist of writing prompts playing with different themes, styles, voices, perspectives, etc. A prompt is given, a time limit is set, everyone writes as much as they can or want, and then people are encouraged to read what they've written aloud. The last half-hour will consist of personal, private critiques, so attendees are encouraged to bring 1-2 pages of their work to share and receive feedback from workshop facilitators.  Speakers include:Jen Haeger, Christine Daigle, Stewart Sternberg

Subject: Reading/Signing: Michael W. Lucas and Ken MacGregor
Description: Join our attending authors in the Writers Block (317 & 318) for readings and signings!  Speakers include:Michael W. Lucas, Ken MacGregor

Subject: Speak Your Words
Description: We are all made of stories and sharing them can be powerful and life changing. Come and share our version of an open mic night.  Bring your self-written poetry, personal manifesto, or short-short story.  Speakers include:Jim Leach, Matt Betts, Sean M Davis, Jessica Roland

Subject: Reading/Signing: Tobias S. Buckell and Mark Oshiro
Description: Join our attending authors in the Writers Block (317 & 318) for readings and signings!  Speakers include:Tobias S. Buckell, Mark Oshiro

Subject: Erotica in Speculative Fiction
Description: Birds do it, bees do it, and elves and aliens do it. Our panelists talk about erotica in science fiction and fantasy genre fiction.  Speakers include:Ken MacGregor, Jay Maynard, Dave Klecha, Jeff Pryor

Subject: SF/F Madlibs
Description: Enjoy science fiction, fantasy, and pop culture Mad-libs created by our panelists. Offer up some interesting nouns, adj, verbs and adverbs and be prepared to laugh your head off!  Speakers include:Andrea Johnson, Jackie Morgan, Jen Haeger, Alex Kourvo, Catherynne Valente

Subject: Story Roundtabling
Description: Join us for some dynamic story exercises! Start with a simple plot and develop it around the table. Each person is given a chance to tell the next part in turn. Any change can be made by the next storyteller. Each turn is no more than two minutes. We join the story where our heroes are about to land on Saturn F-Ring station in search of whoever stole the E-nabling 3D printed thumb-drive. The smart drive will enable anyone who wears it to break the security codes used by banks and stock markets throughout the solar system. This session will be recorded and posted on YouTube with participant permission.  Speakers include:Gibson Nichols

Subject: Tools for Outlines: M.I.C.E., The Three Act Structure
Description: Is your story about Milieu, an Idea, a Character, or an Event? Figure out what sort of story you want to tell, and see which elements are most important, how you might want to structure the story, and how to tell if you've reached the end.   Speakers include:Paul Kemner, Ericka S. Kahler, Eric S. Raymond, Michael K. Elliot

Subject: Writing Risks
Description: Sometimes it can seem as if marketing departments are only after rehashes of the latest hot thing, at the cost of originality and diversity. Are diverse characters, genre mashups, and unusual structures a benefit to the sales department or a hindrance? How can authors challenge new boundaries and still make the editors, agents and other gatekeepers happy and produce a book with mass appeal? Does this strategy change further into an author's career? Authors talk genre and classification and all the other challenges for this difficult subject.  Speakers include:Ann Leckie, Tobias S. Buckell, Christian Klaver, Salathiel Palland, Michael Cieslak

Subject: Self-Publishing 2016
Description: This panel discusses today's self-publishing options and business models. Our panelists include authors who are both self- and traditionally published, in fiction and nonfiction, including people who are making an income entirely by self-publishing. We'll discuss why we made the choice to self-publish, the pitfalls and lessons learned, and which business choices we've made on our respective self-publishing efforts.  Speakers include:Michael W. Lucas, Jen Haeger, Christopher Purrett, Alex Kourvo, Robert Kroese

Subject: What Have You Read?
Description: What's something amazing that you read recently that you want to tell the world about?  Speakers include:Jim Leach, Andrea Johnson, Stewart Sternberg, Nicole Castle

Subject: Catherynne Valente Reading
Description: Join Guest of Honor Catherynne Valente for a reading and a chance to have your books signed.  Speakers include:Catherynne Valente

Subject: Reading/Signing: Marie Staver
Description: Join our attending authors in the Writers Block (317 & 318) for readings and signings!  Speakers include:Marie Staver

Subject: Self Editing Tools
Description: Before you expose your precious words to others, you want them to look their best. Clif will discuss a few of the off-the-shelf tools for grammar checking your work with emphasis on checkIt (potential name change), a tool written by a writer for writers to make their prose stronger.  Speakers include:Clif Flynt, Sean M Davis

Subject: Star Wars: Bane or Boon?
Description: Was the latest Star Wars groundbreaking and subversive? Or was it just merely a rehash of old tropes? Do new characters like Rey, Finn, Po, and Kylo Ren hold up to classic characters such as Luke, Leia, Han and Darth Vader. When does using standard archetypes degrade into rehash and did Star Wars fall into this trap or transcend expectations?  Speakers include:Jon David, Ferrett Steinmetz, Michael K. Elliot, Salathiel Palland, Michael Cieslak

Subject: Reading/Signing: Emmy Jackson, David Erik Nelson
Description: Join our attending authors in the Writers Block (317 & 318) for readings and signings!  Speakers include:Emmy Jackson, David Erik Nelson

Subject: The Most Useful Tropes
Description: Cliches in fantasy and science fiction are a big no-no... except when they arent. What are the most-used tropes in SFF? Why are they so overused? Are they always bad? Are there ways they can be twisted to say new things about the genre?  Speakers include:Emmy Jackson, Jackie Morgan, Scott Favre, Mark Oshiro

Subject: Reading/Signing: Rosemary Van Deuren and Clarence 'Zig Zag Claybourne' Young
Description: Join our attending authors in the Writers Block (317 & 318) for readings and signings!  Speakers include:Rosemary Van Deuren, Clarence 'Zig Zag Claybourne' Young

Subject: Mechanics of Magic in Fantasy & SF
Description: Does a magical system for a story need rules? Costs, unintended consequences, social factors? What about reliability issues? How can we avoid worn-out tropes. How should magic in an RPG and story differ? Is some of the tech in SF 'magic' and should the same considerations apply?  Speakers include:Paul Kemner, Ericka S. Kahler, Eric S. Raymond, Andrew Zimmerman Jones

Subject: Teens of the Wasteland
Description: Why do so many contemporary YA novels feature a post-apocalyptic setting with teens on a journey across what remains of civilization? What needs to these books fulfill, and has the wave of their popularity already peaked? If so, whats next?  Speakers include:Emmy Jackson, Jon David, Janice Leach

Subject: Reading/Signing: Christine Daigle & Stewart Sternberg
Description: Join our attending authors in the Writers Block (317 & 318) for readings and signings!  Speakers include:Christine Daigle, Stewart Sternberg
